channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Mysterious Type Of Killer Whale, Sought After For Years, Found In Southern Ocean
item.description: The notion that there might be some new kind of killer whale emerged in 1955, when photos from New Zealand showed a bunch of unusual-looking whales stranded on a beach.
item.content:encoded:
The notion that there might be some new kind of killer whale emerged in 1955, when photos from New Zealand showed a bunch of unusual-looking whales stranded on a beach.

(Image credit: Courtesy of J.P. Sylvestre)
item.dc:creator: Christopher Joyce

item.title: An Antibody-Inspired Small Molecule Could Make For A Better Flu Treatment
item.description: To outsmart influenza, researchers are leveraging the biological information encoded in infection-fighting antibodies to design new drugs. One attempt neutralizes near-lethal levels of flu in mice.
item.content:encoded:
To outsmart influenza, researchers are leveraging the biological information encoded in infection-fighting antibodies to design new drugs. One attempt neutralizes near-lethal levels of flu in mice.

(Image credit: Steve Gschmeissner/Science Source)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: How Much Is Today's HIV Research Centered Around The Search For A Cure?
item.description: For the second time ever, a man's HIV infection has been sent into remission. NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Rowena Johnston, director of research for the Foundation for AIDS Research.
item.content:encoded: For the second time ever, a man's HIV infection has been sent into remission. NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with Rowena Johnston, director of research for the Foundation for AIDS Research.

item.title: Bone Marrow Transplant Renders Second Patient Free Of HIV
item.description: British doctors report the apparent eradication of HIV from a patient who was undergoing treatment for cancer. It's only the second time this has been accomplished, despite many attempts.
item.content:encoded:
British doctors report the apparent eradication of HIV from a patient who was undergoing treatment for cancer. It's only the second time this has been accomplished, despite many attempts.

(Image credit: SCIENCE SOURCE)
item.dc:creator: Richard Harris

item.title: Deus Ex...Artificial Intelligence?
item.description: There are just nine companies that Professor Amy Webb says control the future of AI.
item.content:encoded:
There are just nine companies that Professor Amy Webb says control the future of AI.

(Image credit: Elena Seibert)

item.title: London Patient Cleared Of HIV
item.description: Doctors in London say they've successfully treated an HIV patient, but the treatment is dangerous and expensive. The news comes 12 years after a different patient was declared cured of AIDS.
item.content:encoded: Doctors in London say they've successfully treated an HIV patient, but the treatment is dangerous and expensive. The news comes 12 years after a different patient was declared cured of AIDS.
item.dc:creator: David Greene

item.title: How Federal Disaster Money Favors The Rich
item.description: The federal government spends billions of dollars each year helping communities rebuild after disasters and to prevent future damage. But that money isn't always allocated to those who need it most.
item.content:encoded:
The federal government spends billions of dollars each year helping communities rebuild after disasters and to prevent future damage. But that money isn't always allocated to those who need it most.

(Image credit: Claire Harbage/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Hersher

item.title: Storytelling Instead Of Scolding: Inuit Say It Makes Their Children More Cool-Headed
item.description: At the top of the world, parents have figured out how to discipline kids without yelling, scolding or even speaking in an angry tone. Their secret is an ancient tool that sculpts children's behavior.
item.content:encoded: At the top of the world, parents have figured out how to discipline kids without yelling, scolding or even speaking in an angry tone. Their secret is an ancient tool that sculpts children's behavior.
item.dc:creator: Michaeleen Doucleff

item.title: Is Your Child An Orchid Or A Dandelion? Unlocking The Science Of Sensitive Kids
item.description: Some kids seem resilient from the start — readily able, like dandelions, to cope with stress and adversity. But pediatrician Thomas Boyce says biologically reactive kids need more support to thrive.
item.content:encoded:
Some kids seem resilient from the start — readily able, like dandelions, to cope with stress and adversity. But pediatrician Thomas Boyce says biologically reactive kids need more support to thrive.

(Image credit: Michael H/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Dave Davies

item.title: Social Media May Sway Kids To Eat More Cookies — And More Calories
item.description: It's well-known that junk food ads on TV can strongly influence what kids want to eat. A study finds social media influencers can have the same effect on kids, but not when it comes to healthy foods.
item.content:encoded:
It's well-known that junk food ads on TV can strongly influence what kids want to eat. A study finds social media influencers can have the same effect on kids, but not when it comes to healthy foods.

(Image credit: Jessica Lee Photography/Getty Images/Image Source)
item.dc:creator: Patti Neighmond

item.title: SpaceX Crew Dragon Lands Crucial Station Docking
item.description: The SpaceX capsule has docked at the International Space Station. It's the first U.S. spacecraft capable of carrying humans to be launched since NASA stopped developing its own space shuttles in 2011.
item.content:encoded: The SpaceX capsule has docked at the International Space Station. It's the first U.S. spacecraft capable of carrying humans to be launched since NASA stopped developing its own space shuttles in 2011.

item.title: Arizona Lawmakers Consider Loosening Vaccination Requirements
item.description: Measles outbreaks have prompted some states to consider tightening up laws that allow exemptions from vaccines for personal or philosophical reasons. But in Arizona, lawmakers are going the other way.
item.content:encoded: Measles outbreaks have prompted some states to consider tightening up laws that allow exemptions from vaccines for personal or philosophical reasons. But in Arizona, lawmakers are going the other way.
item.dc:creator: Will Stone

item.title: 'Hard Capture Is Complete': SpaceX Capsule Docks With International Space Station
item.description: SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule successfully docked with the International Space Station Sunday. SpaceX is demonstrating the potential for a company to carry astronauts into orbit.
item.content:encoded:
SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule successfully docked with the International Space Station Sunday. SpaceX is demonstrating the potential for a company to carry astronauts into orbit.

(Image credit: Terry Renna/AP)
item.dc:creator: James Doubek

item.title: 'Mama's Last Hug' Makes Case That Humans Are Not Alone In Experiencing Emotions
item.description: In his new book, primate behavior researcher Frans de Waal writes that "emotions are everywhere in the animal kingdom, from fish to birds to insects and even in brainy mollusks such as the octopus."
item.content:encoded:
In his new book, primate behavior researcher Frans de Waal writes that "emotions are everywhere in the animal kingdom, from fish to birds to insects and even in brainy mollusks such as the octopus."

(Image credit: AFP/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Barbara J. King

item.title: Your Questions About Italy's GMO Mosquito Experiment, Answered
item.description: What are some of the leading arguments against this experiment? What happens to other species in the food chain? Isn't developing a vaccine a better way to go?
item.content:encoded:
What are some of the leading arguments against this experiment? What happens to other species in the food chain? Isn't developing a vaccine a better way to go?

(Image credit: Pierre Kattar for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein
